item.title: US Congressional Iran Briefings Postponed After Ceasefire Agreement
item.description: Bipartisan congressional briefings on the weekend US strike on Iranian nuclear facilities have been postponed as Iran and Israel appeared Tuesday to honor a ceasefire agreement.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: The doors to the Senate Parliamentarian's office at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 23, 2025. President Donald Trump's tax-and-spending agenda is nearing a climactic vote in the Senate this week in the wake of air strikes on Iran, which risk embroiling the US in a prolonged Middle East conflict.

item.title: Harvard Wins Longer Block on Trump’s Foreign Student Ban
item.description: A federal judge issued another court order letting Harvard University keep hosting foreign students, this one in its fight to overturn President Donald Trump’s proclamation barring their entry to the US.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

item.title: Spain Regulator to Get More Powers to Oversee Electricity System
item.description: Spain’s government will give the country’s competition authority more powers to supervise private operators’ management of electricity voltage following the nationwide blackout in April.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: Electricity transmission towers in Castellon, Spain.

item.title: Labour Rebels Threaten to Kill Starmer’s UK Welfare Cuts
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he would push ahead with controversial cuts to UK disability benefits despite a sizable rebellion brewing within his own Labour Party that threatens to derail the plan.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Lucy White

media:content.media:description: The Houses of Parliament in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Lithuania Pleads With US to Keep Troop Presence Ahead of Review
item.description: Lithuania called on the US to maintain its military presence on the European Union’s eastern flank while playing down the risk that Washington’s planned review of troops would leave the countries bordering Russia exposed.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Crook, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Kestutis Budrys on June 24. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Sparks Fear Over NATO Future With Doubts on Defense Pledge
item.description: Secretary General Mark Rutte is fighting to stop the NATO summit from spinning out of control after President Donald Trump cast doubt on the US commitment to defend its allies.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Andrea Palasciano, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks with reporters before boarding Marine One on the South Lawn of the White House. Photographer: Evan Vucci/AP Photo

item.title: Trump Amps Up Pressure on GOP Holdouts on His Massive Tax Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump is ratcheting up pressure on Republican holdouts on his multi-trillion dollar tax bill while he’s participating in the annual NATO Summit in the Netherlands this week amid entrenched GOP divisions that put a self-imposed July 4 deadline at risk.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz, Erik Wasson, Cam Kettles

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Truce Between Israel and Iran Back On After Trump Lashes Out
item.description: Israel and Iran appeared to be honoring a ceasefire agreement unexpectedly announced by US President Donald Trump overnight, after the American leader reacted angrily to early breaches of the deal by both sides.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Hadriana Lowenkron, Golnar Motevalli

item.title: French Government Under Pressure as Pension Talks Stumble
item.description: Negotiations over France’s contentious retirement reform ended in deadlock late Monday, raising pressure on the government as some opposition parties called for a no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: Trump Eases Pressure on Iran by Saying China Can Buy Its Oil
item.description: President Donald Trump said China can continue to purchase oil from Iran, abruptly easing the “maximum pressure” the US had been applying to the Middle Eastern country’s economic lifeblood.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith

media:content.media:description: A refinery on the South Pars Gas-Condensate field in Asalouyeh Seaport in Iran.

item.title: How Ranked-Choice Voting Could Sway New York’s Mayoral Primary
item.description: Primary day in New York City’s mayoral contest has arrived, and there’s plenty of drama.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Stacie Sherman

media:content.media:description: New York City mayoral candidates Zohran Mamdani, left, and Andrew Cuomo Photographer: Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/AP Photo/Bloomberg, Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Deeply Scarred Middle East Grasps for Calm After 12 Days of War
item.description: After a shaky ceasefire, the question is what comes next. But people in the region — like investors and oil traders — are taking it in their stride.
item.dc:creator: Neil Munshi, Fiona MacDonald, Peter Martin

item.title: Trump Team Weighed Range of Options for Oil Supply Disruptions
item.description: Trump administration officials considered a range of options in case of a major oil supply disruption in the Middle East ahead of the US strikes on Iran and President Donald Trump’s ceasefire declaration, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 24, 2025. Trump called on Israel to stop dropping bombs on Iran, calling it a "major violation" of a fragile ceasefire between the two countries he announced just hours ago.

item.title: Trump Discloses Flattering Private Message From NATO Chief Rutte
item.description: Leaders beware of texting with Donald Trump, you might just find your private correspondence leaked by the US president himself on Truth Social for global consumption.
item.dc:creator: Flavia Krause-Jackson

media:content.media:description: Secretary general of NATO Mark Rutte during a news conference ahead of the NATO summit in The Hague on June 23.

item.title: Trump’s Chip Tariff Threat Sparks Pushback From Auto Industry to Tech
item.description: Blowback to President Donald Trump’s idea of tariffs on imported semiconductors is proving to be broad and deep, stretching from auto companies and boat makers to the technology industry and crypto enthusiasts, according to a review of more than 150 public comments on the proposal.
item.dc:creator: Michael Shepard

media:content.media:description: A stacker sorts silicon wafers. Photographer: Kyle Green/Bloomberg

item.title: Erdogan to Seek Support From Merz for Eurofighter Sale to Turkey
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan plans to seek support from German Chancellor Friedrich Merz for the sale of Eurofighter jets to Turkey at talks on the sidelines of the NATO summit.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu, Firat Kozok

media:content.media:description: A Eurofighter Typhoon military jet at the Paris Air Show on June 16.

item.title: Trump Questions US Commitment to Defend Allies Before NATO Meets
item.description: President Donald Trump cast doubt on exactly how far the US is prepared to go to defend its NATO allies as he headed to a crucial summit with leaders of the military alliance.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of the media on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 24, 2025. Trump called on Israel to stop dropping bombs on Iran, calling it a “major violation” of a fragile ceasefire between the two countries he announced just hours ago.

item.title: UK to Spend 5% of GDP on Security by 2035 to Hit NATO Goal
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer will vow to spend 5% of British economic output on security by 2035, embracing an ambitious NATO target sought by President Donald Trump without providing a path on how to get there.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer.

item.title: Powell Says Interest Rates Are Now ‘Modestly’ Restrictive

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the US Federal Reserve Jerome Powell during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, on June 24.

item.title: Pressure for Trump Trade Deals Ramps Up With Two Weeks to Go
item.description: Two weeks from President Donald Trump’s self-imposed deadline to reach deals with the US’s major trading partners, some of the most-watched talks aimed at clinching agreements to avoid higher tariffs are struggling to get over the finish line.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: A worker moves a shipping container at Felixstowe port in Felixstowe, UK.

item.title: Putin Going to War With NATO Would Cost World $1.5 Trillion
item.description: The NATO chief says Russia may be ready for an attack on eastern Europe within five years. Bloomberg Economics ran the numbers on what that would mean.
item.dc:creator: Alex Kokcharov, Jennifer Welch, Alberto Nardelli, Julia Janicki, Tom Fevrier, Alex Newman, Tom Orlik, Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Soldiers of the German 45th Armoured Brigade at a ceremonial roll-call in Vilnius, on May 22. Germany is in the process of deploying a 5,000-strong brigade to Lithuania on a permanent basis. Photographer: Paulius Peleckis/Getty Images Europe

item.title: There Is No One-and-Done on Iran
item.description: Trump still faces tough calls that will decide the future of non-proliferation.
item.dc:creator: Marc Champion

media:content.media:description: An Iranian woman checks an Iranian Red Crescent ambulance that was destroyed during an Israeli strike, displayed in Tehran on June 23, 2025.

item.title: Elizabeth Warren Blasts Regulators’ Potential Bank Leverage-Rule Changes
item.description: US Senator Elizabeth Warren criticized potential reforms to a key bank capital buffer ahead of regulators’ meetings this week, saying the rule is a “critical safeguard” that promotes financial stability.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat from Massachusetts

item.title: Germany to Sell More Debt to Fund Growth and Defense Plans
item.description: Germany will borrow about a fifth more than planned in the coming months to help fund a surge in spending, while a deal to secure a €46 billion ($53 billion) package of tax breaks highlighted how debt needs are set to grow.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

item.title: Russian Crude Exports Touch Two-Month Low as Pacific Flows Slump
item.description: Shipments dropped on maintenance at Kozmino and a slowdown at Primorsk
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: Russia shipped 3.19 million barrels a day of crude in the four weeks to June 22, the lowest in more than two months.

item.title: Nigeria Arrests Ex-CFO of State Oil Firm Over Alleged Fraud
item.description: Nigeria’s anti-graft authorities arrested the former chief financial officer of the state oil company and a former head of a refinery in connection with an alleged misappropriation of funds.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: Gas flares burn at an oil flow station in Nigeria. Photographer: George Osodi/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Requests Arrest Warrant for Former President Yoon
item.description: A special counsel investigating former South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol’s imposition of martial law has requested an arrest warrant, citing his repeated refusal to comply with summonses, the counsel’s office said.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Former president of South Korea Yoon Suk Yeol attends a hearing for his impeachment trial at the Constitutional Court in Seoul, on Jan. 23.

item.title: Republican Move to Mask $3.8 Trillion Tax-Cut Cost Rings Alarms
item.description: Senate Republicans are aiming to wipe away some $3.8 trillion of federal budget red ink from the GOP’s signature tax-and-spending bill with an unprecedented parliamentary maneuver, stoking concerns about long-term US fiscal policy.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: NATO Cash Bonanza May Become Europe’s Lost Chance for Growth
item.description: Europe’s plans to unleash trillions of euros in new defense spending will be a huge missed opportunity unless the region can work out how to raise productivity in the process.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: A soldier on patrol ahead of the summit in The Hague, on June 23. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai PM Faces Legal Tests After Averting Coalition Collapse
item.description: Thailand’s anti-graft agency will probe Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s controversial phone call with ex-Cambodian leader Hun Sen, according to local media reports, as her rivals seek legal recourse to force her ouster.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat, Anuchit Nguyen

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra
